title.narrative: Förberedande stöd National Environmental Centre Moldova
Preparatory Support National Environmental Centre Moldova

description.narrative:
Det förberedande kärnstödet för NEC bereds som en förenklad insats. Syftet med det förberedande kärnstödet är att stärka organisationens kapacitet och utveckla deras interna regelverk.
NEC kommer under denna första fas av stödet (innan kärnstöd) att genomföra prioriterade rekommendationer från NCG från system based audit rapporten framtagen 2019. Därför kommer NEC att utveckla institutionell kapacitet, interna rutiner, personalkunskaper och andra färdigheter för att kunna genomföra kärnstödsaktiviteter. Baserat på en kommande uppföljningsrapport som avser aktiviteter under denna första fas (rapport tas preliminärt fram i april 2020) kan Sida sedan överväga att fortsätta med kärnstöd till NEC baserat på en strategisk plan, resultatram och den strategiska budgeten som utvecklats inför kärnstödet.
Insatsens totala budget uppgår till 258 681 SEK.

The pre-core support granted for NEC is a simplified contribution which aims at supporting the organization to develop its internal capacities and policies.
During pre-core support phase NEC will implement priority recommendations provided by the Nordic Consulting Group in the system-based audit report produced in 2019. Therefore, it will develop institutional capacities, internal routines, staff knowledge and skills to be able to implement core-support activities. Based on a follow-up report on pre-core activities to be conducted tentatively in April 2020, Sida may consider continuing with core-support with NEC based on the Strategic Plan, RAF and strategic budget developed during pre-core support.
The interventions' total budget is 258 681 SEK.

The objective of the intervention is to support the institutional development of the organization and to support it in adopting Results Based Management Approach as well as to integrated in its strategic documents environment, gender equality and conflict sensitivity perspectives.

description.narrative:
NEC has developed a draft strategic plan entitled Development Strategy 2020-2023 of the National Environmental Centre and a RAF.
Both the Development Strategy and the RAF have been prepared with the active involvement of all staff members. The focus and scope of the Development Strategy have been discussed at weekly staff meetings, and staff members have been assigned responsibilities for the preparation of different sections of the document and of the RAF. As indicated in interviews, the current draft documents have been shared with the Board for comments and suggestions (but have not yet been discussed at a Board meeting). The 40-page draft Development Strategy includes: An overview of NEC, its vision and structure; A detailed description of the three core areas of intervention (i.e. water resource management, waste management, and green economy and climate change); Provisions for a sub-granting programme and an internship programme; A section on organisational development and increasing visibility; A section on risk management, and; A section on resource mobilisation.
It is noteworthy that NEC did not look at the strategic plans of other organisations for inspiration or use the help of external consultant to facilitate the strategic planning process (which several other CSOs supported by the Embassy have done). In contrast to good practice, the Development Strategy is not grounded in a SWOT exercise, a Theory of Change analysis, stakeholder mapping or other, similar steps that provide a baseline and analysis of the context and could promote critical assessment and out-of-the box thinking. This is a missed opportunity.
Other standard elements that are missing from the draft Development Strategy include: Clear and succinct vision and mission statements and definition of core values; A risk matrix (the section on risk management does not identify risks, it only describes the procedures for risk management); Strategic objectives for organisational development (the section on “organisational development and increasing visibility” only describes NEC’s communication strategy); A provision stipulating how and when the Development Strategy should be reviewed and adjusted, as necessary.
The draft RAF defines strategic priorities, results (intermediate outcomes, immediate outcomes and outputs), indicators, baselines, targets, monitoring frequency and means of verification. NEC has requested that the Team provide feedback on the draft RAF, especially since the organisation has not received any prior coaching. A closer look at the RAF reveals the following shortcomings: Impact statements and related indicators are missing; The indicators defined for different levels of results are similar and mostly output-oriented. “Higher-level” indicators have to be defined for the intermediate outcomes and impact; The RAF contains an unmanageable number of indicators (close to 100). Collecting, analysing and reporting on all the required data would be very time-consuming, especially for a small organisation like NEC; For several indicators the monitoring frequency is defined as “permanent”. It would be more practical to do the monitoring periodically, e.g. every month or quarter. The means of verification are not well-defined and all consists of internal NEC documents. It would be appropriate to include some independent sources as means of verification for the intermediate outcomes and impact. NEC could also consider conducting a survey to properly measure indicators related to “increased capacity” and “public awareness”.
NEC has produced an administrative budget for 2020 as well as a comprehensive annual report for 2019. However, these documents are not linked to the Development Strategy or RAF.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
